docs.title: Welcome to Version Management Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to our versioning documentation using MkDocs and mike. This documentation will help you understand how to manage different versions of your documentation effectively.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Install required packages
  2. Set up your mkdocs.yml
  3. Deploy your first version
  4. Manage multiple versions

Check our Installation Guide to get started.

docs.title: About Our Documentation
docs.text: This documentation system uses: - MkDocs for documentation generation - Material theme for beautiful styling - Mike for version management - GitHub Pages for hosting

docs.title: Why Version Control?
docs.text: Version control for documentation is crucial when: - Maintaining multiple releases - Supporting different product versions - Providing historical documentation - Managing breaking changes

docs.title: Welcome to Version 3.3
docs.text: This page demonstrates how to use version-specific content. The current version of this documentation is 3.3.

docs.title: Version Testing Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Deploy new version
  • [ ] Verify version selector
  • [ ] Check navigation
  • [ ] Validate links
  • [ ] Test search functionality

docs.title: Basic Installation
docs.text:
pip install mkdocs
pip install mkdocs-material
pip install mike

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
1. Create mkdocs.yml:
site_name: My Dummy Project
repo_url: https://github.com/M-E-U-E/versioning
site_dir: site

theme:
  name: material

plugins:
  - search
  - mike

extra:
  version:
    provider: mike
    default: latest
    name: 1.1
    alias: latest

docs.title: What is Mike?
docs.text:
Mike is a versatile tool for managing multiple versions of your documentation. It works seamlessly with MkDocs and provides:

  • Version-specific documentation
  • Easy deployment
  • Version aliases
  • Simple version switching

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
1. Multiple version support
  2. Version aliases
  3. Default version selection
  4. GitHub Pages integration

docs.title: Version Management Workflow
docs.text:
1. Make documentation changes
  2. Commit changes to git
  3. Deploy new version
  4. Update aliases if needed
  5. Serve locally to verify

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use semantic versioning
  2. Maintain clear version notes
  3. Test locally before deployment
  4. Keep version aliases consistent
